MOLCAA 9846 S1381-1169(16)30124-8 10.1016/j.molcata.2016.04.002 Scheme 1 Transesterification of phenol with DMC to synthesize DPC. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 XRD patterns (a) and enlarged peaks at 2θ=28.2, 30.2 and 31.5° (b) of the samples. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 H2-TPR profiles of the samples. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Binding energies of Zr 3d5/2 (a), Pb 4f7/2 (b) and O 1s (c) of the samples. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (a), (b) and pore diameter distributions (c) of the samples. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Effect of calcination temperature. Reaction conditions: 200°C, 3h, 1.0g catalyst. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Leaching test of 15.2PbZr in the disproportionation of MPC (■ with 15.2PbZr, ● filtrate without 15.2PbZr). Reaction conditions: 200°C, 1.0g catalyst. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Reusability of 15.2PbZr. Reaction conditions: 200°C, 2.5h, 1.2g catalyst. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 XRD pattern (a) and FT-IR spectra (b) of fresh and used 15.2PbZr. Highly efficient and stable PbO–ZrO2 catalyst for the disproportionation of methyl phenyl carbonate to synthesize diphenyl carbonate Songlin Wang a b Changgong Li a Zhongliang Xiao b Tong Chen b ⁎ Gongying Wang b a School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Henan Institute of Science and Technology, Xinxiang 453003, PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Henan Institute of Science and Technology Xinxiang 453003 PR China b Chengdu Institute of Organic Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Chengdu 610041, PR China Chengdu Institute of Organic Chemistry Chinese Academy of Sciences Chengdu 610041 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author at: Chengdu Institute of Organic Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, PR China. Chengdu Institute of Organic Chemistry Chinese Academy of Sciences Chengdu 610041 PR China Graphical abstract Heterogeneous PbO–ZrO2 catalysts (PbZr) were first prepared by coprecipitation method, and used to catalyze the liquid-phase disproportionation reaction of methyl phenyl carbonate (MPC) to synthesize diphenyl carbonate (DPC). PbZr with PbO loading of 15.2wt% (15.2PbZr) exhibited the best catalytic performance. Under the optimal conditions (200°C, 2.5h, and 1.2g catalyst), the conversion of MPC reached 76.6% and the selectivity of DPC was 99.3%, respectively, which were significantly higher than those of heterogeneous catalysts reported before. The characterization results of XPS, H2-TPR, XRD and BET analyses showed that 15.2PbZr gave the strongest interaction between Pb and Zr, the highest dispersion of PbO as well as the largest surface area and pore volume. Moreover, for 15.2PbZr, though reused for five recycles, the conversion of MPC still reached 75% and the selectivity of DPC was kept at 99.0%, implying that 15.2PbZr represented superior reusability. Besides, the structure of the 15.2PbZr after five times reaction was almost identical to that of the fresh, and Pb was almost not leached out of the catalyst, indicating that the stability of Pb species was improved, due to the existence of favorable interaction between Pb and Zr as well as part of the Pb entering into ZrO2 structure. Thus, 15.2PbZr may serve as a promising catalyst for MPC disproportionation. Keywords Diphenyl carbonate Disproportionation Methyl phenyl carbonate PbO–ZrO2 Heterogeneous catalyst 1 Introduction Diphenyl carbonate (DPC) is extensively employed to produce various organic compounds and polymer materials, especially utilized as an important precursor for the synthesis of polycarbonate to substitute phosgene [1–3]. The transesterification of dimethyl carbonate (DMC) and phenol is the most prospective route to synthesize DPC without using phosgene [4,5]. This route is a two-step process [6,7]. In the first step, intermediate methyl phenyl carbonate (MPC) is formed by the transesterification of phenol and DMC (Scheme 1 , Eq. (1)), and in the second step, MPC is converted into DPC by the further transesterification of MPC with phenol (Scheme 1, Eq. (2)) or the disproportionation of MPC (Scheme 1, Eq. (3)). The equilibrium constants K2 (1.2×10−5, 25°C) and K3 (0.19, 25°C) showed that DPC was mainly generated by the disproportionation of MPC rather than the further transesterification of MPC. The first step is the rate-controlling step, since the equilibrium constant K1 (6.3×10−5, 25°C) is much smaller than K3 even at elevated temperatures [8,9]. Thus, strenuous efforts have been devoted to the first-step transesterification of phenol and DMC [10–17], while the independent disproportionation of MPC is rarely reported [18–20]. To maximize the yield of DPC, the research concentrated on the disproportionation to improve the conversion of MPC is also very important. Some homogeneous catalytic processes have been researched using Bu2SnO, BuSnO(OH), Bu2Sn(OCOC11H23)2 and Bu3SnOSnBu3 in the disproportionation of MPC [18], but these catalysts are complicated to be separated from the products and recovered for the reuse. Therefore, several heterogeneous catalysts have been explored using various metal oxides like PbO, CuO, TiO2, V2O5, MoO3 and SnO2, and PbO presents outstanding catalytic performance with MPC conversion of 58.2% and DPC selectivity of 99.2% [20]. However, the dissolution of PbO still leads to difficulty for the separation of the product and the catalyst, as well as the loss of Pb and residual contamination [21]. Thus, it is quite demanded to further develop highly efficient catalysts for catalyzing MPC disproportionation. In recent years, ZrO2 as catalyst support with high thermal stability, chemical durability and large surface area has attracted a great deal of attention. Several ZrO2-based composite metal oxides such as MoO3–ZrO2 [22], Cr2O3–ZrO2 [23] and BiCl3–ZrO2 [24] have already been reported, which are highly active and recyclable in many important liquid-phase reactions including acetalization of 1, 3-propanediol, ethanol dehydration/dehydrogenation and synthesis of pyrazolyl chalcones [22–24]. Therefore, in this paper, ZrO2 is selected as the support to disperse the Pb species and stabilize the active Pb components in order to promote the catalytic activity of PbO. Heterogeneous PbO–ZrO2 catalysts are firstly prepared by coprecipitation method, and used to catalyze the disproportionation of MPC. To investigate the relationship of structure and the catalytic property, catalysts are characterized by XRD, XPS, H2-TPR, FT-IR and BET experiment. Additionally, the influence of the structural property on the stability of the catalyst is also researched. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials preparation The PbO–ZrO2 catalysts was prepared by coprecipitation method [22,25]. Zirconyl chloride octahydrate (ZrOCl2·8H2O, ≥99%), lead nitrate (Pb(NO3)2, ≥99%) and ammonia hydroxide (28–30%) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. A detailed process was as follows: 11.0g ZrOCl2·8H2O and desirable amount of Pb(NO3)2 were added into 100mL deionized water, and then the mixture was heated to 90°C to completely dissolve the solids. Afterwards, ammonium hydroxide was added dropwise into the above solution with rigorous stirring until the final solution pH was 9.3. The resulting solids were aged at 60°C for 24h, followed by filtration and washed with distilled water. The obtained samples were then dried at 110°C overnight and calcined at 600°C in air for 5h. The mixed oxides are denoted as xPbZr, where x is the loading amount of PbO (wt%) (calculated by the atom molar ratio of Pb to Zr). For comparison, pure ZrO2 and PbO were prepared by the same method. Supported PbO/ZrO2 catalysts were prepared with mechanical milling method and impregnation method, respectively. For the mechanical milling method, ZrO2 and Pb(NO3)2 were mixed and ground uniformly, and then the mixture was calcined at 600°C for 5h. As to the impregnation method, ZrO2 was impregnated by appropriate amount of Pb(NO3)2 solution at ambient temperature for 24h. The sample was dried at 110°C overnight, and then calcined at 600°C for 5h. Other supported PbO catalysts using different supports, including SiO2, TiO2, MgO and Al2O3, were also prepared by the impregnation method described above. 2.2 Materials characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurement was performed using a X’pert PRO MPD diffractometer (Philip) with Cu Kα (λ=1.54056Å) radiation at 40kV and 45mA in the 2 theta range from 5 to 90°. The diffraction line positions were determined with a scanning rate of 1.2°/min. Temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was carried out using automatic multi-purpose adsorption instrument (Micro TP-5080, Tianjin Xianquan Industry and Trade Development Co., Ltd.). Samples (50mg) were pretreated with flowing N2 (99.999%, 20mL/min) at 400°C for 1h. Before testing, the baseline was stabilized at 30°C in the flowing gas. A 10% (volume fraction) H2 in N2 mixture was used as the reducing gas. The reactor was heated in a temperature-programmed range from 30 to 800°C (10°C/min). The H2 consumption as a function of the reduction temperature was continuously detected by TCD. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was detected on a Kratos Model XSAM 800 apparatus with an Al Kα=1486.6eV exciting X-rays source (15kV, 12mA). The lines were recorded with a narrow sweep width in the range of 5–7eV and an energy pass of 50eV. The binding energies were calibrated by reference of the C1s peak (284.6eV) as internal standard to reduce the charge effect of samples. The textural properties of samples were measured by N2 adsorption/desorption at −196°C using automatic NOVA Win2200E adsorption analyzer (Quantanchrome, USA). Before measurement, samples were treated under high vacuum at 300°C for 3h. The total specific surface area was calculated by multi-point Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method, and the porous distribution were determined by Barrett–Joyner–Hallenda (BJH) method. IR spectra was recorded using Nicolet 560 Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra at room temperature (25°C) with KBr pellets in the range of 4000–400cm−1 and the resolution was 4cm−1. The element contents were determined by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) using an IRIS 1000 instrument (Thermo Electron, USA). 2.3 Catalytic performance tests MPC was synthesized and purified in the laboratory, and its purity was 99.8% determined by high performance liquid chromatography. The disproportionation of MPC was performed in a round-bottomed flask (100mL) with a fractionating column connected to a liquid dividing head. In a typical procedure, MPC (150mmol) and a certain amount of catalyst was added into the reactor under nitrogen atmosphere. The mixture was gradually heated to desired temperature under rigorous stirring, and then the temperature was kept at desired temperature. During the reaction, DMC was continuously distilled out to shift the equilibrium towards DPC. The reaction mixture was quantified by GC–MS on a HP-6890/5973 system. The products were quantitatively analyzed by GC system (Agilent Technologies 7820A) with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a DB-35 capillary column (30m×320μm×0.25μm). The conversion of MPC and selectivity of DPC were calculated by GC results using a correction factor normalization method. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Materials characterization 3.1.1 XRD analysis Generally, ZrO2 mainly exists in the monoclinic, tetragonal and cubic phases, and the tetragonal phase is of importance for catalytic applications due to the high mechanical strength and interesting physicochemical properties [26–28]. The XRD patterns of the samples prepared by coprecipitation method are shown in Fig. 1 (a), and pure ZrO2 exhibits the only monoclinic (2θ=24.8°, 28.2°, 31.5°, 34.1° and 50.4°, JCPDS No. 37-1484) crystalline phases. PbZr with PbO loading of 1.9–15.2% exhibits the coexistence of monoclinic and tetragonal (2θ=30.2°, 35.1°, 50.2° and 60.2°, JCPDS No. 27-997) ZrO2 phases, but the monoclinic structure decreases and the tetragonal structure increases with the increasing of PbO loading. When PbO loading increases to 22.8%, the monoclinic structure almost disappears. The results suggest that Pb promotes the crystalline transformation of zirconia from monoclinic to tetragonal phases. Additionally, as the PbO content increases, the peak positions gradually shift to lower angle (for a clear observation, for example, the peak positions of 2θ=28.2, 30.2 and 31.5° are magnified in Fig. 1(b)), and when the PbO content increases to 30.4%, the peak positions do not shift. This is mainly attributed to the incorporation of Pb ions into the ZrO2 crystal lattice because Pb2+ (1.2nm) is larger than Zr4+ (0.8nm). Significantly, for PbZr samples, no diffraction peaks ascribed to PbO phases can be observed even when the PbO loading is up to 30.4%, indicating that PbO is highly dispersed. However, weak crystalline PbO phase appears when the content is 47.5%. 3.1.2 H2-TPR analysis H2-TPR profiles of PbZr samples are shown in Fig. 2 . The reduction temperature of ZrO2 appears around 625°C, and the reduction temperature of PbO appears at 615°C. Interestingly, the reduction temperature of PbZr is lower than those of PbO and ZrO2. Meanwhile, as PbO loading increasing from 1.9% to 22.8%, the reduction temperature shifts to low temperature, related to the strengthened interaction between Pb and Zr [29,30]. It is noteworthy that the reduction temperatures of PbO loading with 22.8% and 30.4% are basically identical. The reason is probably that the formation of Pb–Zr solid solution leading to the unchanged interaction between Pb and Zr [31–33], which is agreed with the XRD result of the appreciable shifts to low angle of 2θ=30.2° for 22.8PbZr and 30.4PbZr (seen in Fig. 1(b)). However, further increasing the PbO loading to 47.5%, the reduction temperature inversely shifts to high value, trending to that of bulk PbO, which can be attributed to the formation of crystalline PbO. This is also in agreement with the result of XRD analysis. Thus, 15.2% PbO is the appropriate loading before the Pb–Zr solid solution is formed. 3.1.3 XPS analysis XPS spectra of PbZr samples is shown in Fig. 3 . The binding energy of Zr 3d5/2 in ZrO2 is 179eV. As shown in Fig. 3(a), the introduction of Pb increases the binding energy of Zr 3d5/2 to 181.2eV, and with the increase of PbO loading from 3.8% to 22.8%, the binding energy of Zr 3d5/2 further shifts to high value from 181.2eV to 181.8eV. The binding energy of Pb 4f7/2 in PbO is 137eV. As shown in Fig. 3(b), the introduction of Pb also increases the binding energy of Pb 4f7/2, but the variation is less than that of Zr 3d5/2. The binding energies of O 1s in ZrO2 and PbO is 530.2eV and 531.3eV. As shown in Fig. 3(c), the introduction of Pb decreases the binding energy of O 1s. For a clear observation, the deconvolution of O 1s is divided into two Gaussian component peaks of 531.3eV and 529.8eV, which are assigned to the surface absorbed oxygen and lattice oxygen, respectively [34,35]. The binding energy for lattice oxygen shifts to lower value. These phenomena are ascribed to the variation of the electron density around the central atom by the formation of PbOZr bond [36,37]. Owing to much higher electronegativity of O (3.44) than those of Zr (1.33) and Pb (1.54), partial electrons could transfer from Zr and Pb to O through the PbOZr bond, resulting in a rich electron state of O and a deficient electron state of Zr and Pb species. Therefore, the binding energies of Zr 3d5/2 and Pb 4f7/2 rise and the O 1s binding energies reduce. Besides, the electronegativity of Zr and Pb indicates that Zr is easier to lose electron than Pb, thus causing the bigger variation of Zr 3d5/2 binding energy compared to that of Pb 4f7/2. These changes of binding energies further testify that the interaction between Zr and Pb is formed by PbOZr and strengthened with the increasing PbO content. When PbO loading increases to 30.4%, the binding energy slightly changes, suggesting that the interaction between Pb and Zr is close for 22.8PbZr and 30.4PbZr, verifying that the analysis is in good accordance with XRD and H2-TPR results. As PbO loading further increasing to 47.5%, the binding energies of Zr 3d5/2 and Pb 4f7/2 decrease, since the surface is covered by crystalline PbO which reduces the interaction of Zr and Pb [29,30]. Apparently, for PbZr samples, the binding energies of 15.2PbZr have the most remarkable shifts, illustrating the strongest interaction between Zr and Pb. Table 1 displays that the surface atomic ratio of Pb/Zr is far higher than the bulk atomic ratio from the theoretical calculation. This means that more active Pb species migrate from the bulk to the surface, which may be ascribed to the surface segregation of PbO due to the lower melting point of PbO than ZrO2 (melting point 880°C versus 2700°C). The PbO enrichment on the surface would be favorable to improving the catalytic performances of the PbZr. 3.1.4 BET analysis N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm and pore diameter distribution of PbZr samples are shown in Fig. 4 . Fig. 4(a) shows all the isotherms of PbZr (except 47.5PbZr) are typical mesoporous materials. Fig. 4(b) shows the isotherm of 47.5PbZr with little adsorption capacity is similar to that of PbO, due to the formation of crystalline PbO covering the surface of ZrO2. Fig. 4(c) shows that the pore size distribution of ZrO2 is broad, giving an average pore diameter of 8.3nm. However, the pore size distributions of PbZr exhibit relatively homogeneity with the average pore diameter of less than 8.3nm, indicating that the channel change shifts the pore to the small distribution. Nevertheless, the shift is much larger when the PbO loading is greater than 15.2%, because partial channel is blocked by excessive PbO [38]. Clearly, 15.2PbZr displays the highest pore homogeneity, suggesting that 15.2PbZr possesses the largest channel change which benefits to increase the surface area and pore volume. Table 1 lists the textural parameters of these PbZr samples. The introduction of Pb could change the channel, create the new pores, decrease the pore size and enlarge the surface area and pore volume [38]. As PbO loading exceeds 15.2%, the pore could not continue to be created, and further increasing PbO loading blocks up the original pores. Therefore, the surface area and pore volume drop. The results indicate that the PbO loading significantly affects the textural properties of PbZr. Among them, 15.2PbZr owns the largest surface area and pore volume. Additionally, it may be inferred that the formation of Pb−Zr solid solution is not beneficial to the dispersion of PbO, because of the decrease in the surface area and pore volume. 3.2 Results of catalytic performance test 3.2.1 Effect of catalyst support In previous work, different metal oxide catalysts have been explored for MPC disproportionation, and PbO presents high catalytic activity with MPC conversion of 58.2% [20]. Nevertheless, the dissolution of PbO in the reaction is fairly unsatisfactory for its application. As a preliminary exploration of heterogeneous catalysts, supported PbO catalysts with PbO loading of 15.2% on different supports are prepared by impregnation method, and the catalytic activity for MPC disproportionation is listed in Table 2 . Among them, MgO and ZrO2 are suitable supports for the disproportionation of MPC, and more than 60% MPC conversion is attained over PbO/MgO or PbO/ZrO2. However, more byproduct anisole is formed over PbO/MgO, due to the higher basic sites of MgO resulting in the decarboxylation of MPC [39–41]. Accordingly, ZrO2 is selected to use as the support for MPC disproportionation, since DPC selectivity is up to 98.7% over PbO/ZrO2. 3.2.2 Effect of preparation method The effect of preparation methods on the catalytic activity of PbO/ZrO2 is also listed in Table 2. As seen in Table 2, the PbZr prepared by coprecipitation method displays the outstanding disproportionate performance with MPC conversion of 76.6% along with DPC selectivity of 99.3%. Therefore, the coprecipitation method is appropriate to prepare PbZr for MPC disproportionation. 3.2.3 Effect of PbO loading Effect of PbO loading on catalytic performance of PbZr is carefully studied. As can be seen in Table 3 , ZrO2 has almost no catalytic activity. For supported PbO catalysts, the conversion of MPC distinctly increases with PbO loading increase and reaches the maximum of 76.6% at 15.2% loading. However, further increasing PbO loading, MPC conversion maintains at 63−66%, which is close to the conversion value by the catalysts prepared with impregnation method and mechanical milling method. As revealed in the characterization results of XRD, H2-TPR and XPS, when PbO loading is 22.8–30.4%, the Pb–Zr solid solution is formed, and further increasing PbO loading to 47.5%, the dispersion of PbO decreases. As a result, the efficient active sites of PbO do not increase despite the loading is above 15.2%. Therefore, the interaction of Pb and Zr and the surface area are important factors for that 15.2PbZr exhibits higher catalytic activity than others. From the results of XRD, H2-TPR, XPS and BET measurements, 15.2PbZr provides the strongest interaction between Zr and Pb and the maximum surface area, which enables to highly disperse the PbO and afford more efficient exposure of active sites [42–44]. Additionally, this result also suggests that the coprecipitation method dispersing PbO is better than impregnation and mechanical milling method so that the catalyst prepared by coprecipitation method exhibits higher catalytic activity than the other two methods. 3.2.4 Effect of calcination temperature Effect of calcination temperature on the catalytic behavior of 15.2PbZr is shown in Fig. 5 . Below 600°C, the catalytic activity increases with increasing of calcination temperature. When the calcination temperature is 600°C, the conversion of MPC reaches the maximum of 73.3%, and the selectivity of DPC is 99.7%. As calcination temperature further increases, the conversion conversely decreases. From XRD results (Fig. S1, see Supplementary material), at higher than 700°C, the PbO crystalline phases appear [45], implying that PbO is poorly dispersed. Simultaneously, the obvious monoclinic zirconia phases are also observed. Thus, the optimum calcination temperature is 600°C. In order to systematically understand the catalytic reaction, the effect of catalyst amount, reaction temperature as well as the reaction time on the catalytic performance of 15.2PbZr is also optimized (Fig. S2–S4, see Supplementary material). With a catalyst amount of 1.2g, a reaction temperature of 200°C and a reaction time of 2.5h, MPC conversion of 76.6% and DPC selectivity of 99.3% are obtained, respectively. Previous studies have reported that MoO3/SiO2 catalyst exhibits MPC conversion of 72.8% and DPC selectivity of 98.1% under optimum conditions, and it was easily deactivated by the adsorption of carbonate species on the catalyst surface [19]. For comparison, 15.2PbZr reveals superior catalytic activity comparing with PbO and MoO3/SiO2, and has the potential application in industry. 3.3 Reusability of 15.2PbZr The heterogeneity of 15.2PbZr is investigated by a hot leaching test [46,47], and the results are given in Fig. 6 . The catalyst is removed by filtration after the reaction proceeds for 1h, and then the reaction is continued by using the filtrate under the same condition. It is found that the yield of DPC increases as the prolonged time and reaches the highest at 3h, while it keeps almost unchanged in the filtrate without catalyst even prolonging the reaction time to 4h. The leaching test suggests that 15.2PbZr is an efficient and stable heterogeneous catalyst. The reusability of 15.2PbZr is tested by five consecutive runs and the result is illustrated in Fig. 7 . After each reaction, the catalyst is facilely recovered by filtration. As shown in Fig. 8 , the catalyst is reused for five recycles without substantial decrease of activity. Elemental analysis of the filtrates presents that little Pb is leached out of the catalyst after each run (Table S1, see Supplementary material). Besides, as shown in Fig. 8, XRD pattern and FT-IR spectrum show that the crystal phase structures and group compositions of the used 15.2PbZr after five times are identical to those of the fresh 15.2PbZr. Therefore, 15.2PbZr may serve as a highly stable catalyst for MPC disproportionation. Its good stability is mainly attributed to the existence of favorable interaction between Pb and Zr. 4 Conclusions PbZr catalysts with different methods are prepared, and used to catalyze the disproportionation reaction of MPC. 15.2PbZr (PbO loading of 15.2wt% on ZrO2) prepared by coprecipitation method exhibits the best catalytic performance, due to the high dispersion of PbO, the strong interaction between Pb and Zr as well as the large surface area and pore volume. The introduction of Pb promotes the structural transformation of zirconia from monoclinic to tetragonal phases, and part of Pb entering into ZrO2 structure is in favor of improving the stability of Pb species. The formation of Pb–Zr solid solution at PbO loading of 22.8–30.4% decreases the PbO dispersion, which are not beneficial to improve the catalytic activity. Under the optimized conditions (PbO loading of 15.2wt%, calcination temperature of 600°C, catalyst amount of 1.2g, reaction temperature of 200°C and reaction time of 2.5h), MPC conversion of 76.6% and DPC selectivity of 99.3% over 15.2PbZr are attained. Besides, 15.2PbZr after simple separation by filtration could be reused for five recycles without remarkable loss of activity. Also its structural features are maintained well after recycling use. The construction of strong interaction between Pb and Zr (promoting the high dispersion of PbO on ZrO2) plays an important role for fabricating the highly active and stable catalyst. The excellent catalytic performance, easy separation and superior stability indicate that PbZr catalysts deserve more attention and have the potential application in industry. coredata.dc:description: Heterogeneous PbO–ZrO2 catalysts (PbZr) were first prepared by coprecipitation method, and used to catalyze the liquid-phase disproportionation reaction of methyl phenyl carbonate (MPC) to synthesize diphenyl carbonate (DPC). PbZr with PbO loading of 15.2wt% (15.2PbZr) exhibited the best catalytic performance. Under the optimal conditions (200°C, 2.5h, and 1.2g catalyst), the conversion of MPC reached 76.6% and the selectivity of DPC was 99.3%, respectively, which were significantly higher than those of heterogeneous catalysts reported before. The characterization results of XPS, H2-TPR, XRD and BET analyses showed that 15.2PbZr gave the strongest interaction between Pb and Zr, the highest dispersion of PbO as well as the largest surface area and pore volume. Moreover, for 15.2PbZr, though reused for five recycles, the conversion of MPC still reached 75% and the selectivity of DPC was kept at 99.0%, implying that 15.2PbZr represented superior reusability. Besides, the structure of the 15.2PbZr after five times reaction was almost identical to that of the fresh, and Pb was almost not leached out of the catalyst, indicating that the stability of Pb species was improved, due to the existence of favorable interaction between Pb and Zr as well as part of the Pb entering into ZrO2 structure. Thus, 15.2PbZr may serve as a promising catalyst for MPC disproportionation.
coredata.dc:title: Highly efficient and stable PbO–ZrO2 catalyst for the disproportionation of methyl phenyl carbonate to synthesize diphenyl carbonate
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
